NewPuzzle.title: New Puzzle
NewPuzzle.starting-a-new-puzzle-will-overwrite: Starting a new puzzle will overwrite your current puzzle in progress.

StartGame.some-puzzle-sizes-are-disabled-for-harde: Note: some puzzle sizes are disabled for harder puzzles.

BasicRules.description: The goal of a binary puzzle is simple: fill every cell of the grid with a {symbolZero} or a {symbolOne} according to some simple rules. These 3 key rules are:
BasicRules.title: Basic Rules

balanced-lines.title: Balanced Lines
balanced-lines.description-1: Each row and column must have an equal number of {symbolOnePlural} and {symbolZeroPlural}.
balanced-lines.description-2: For example, in a 4x4 grid, each row and column should contain two {symbolOnePlural} and two {symbolZeroPlural}.
balanced-lines.example-correct: There are exactly 3 {symbolZeroPlural} and 3 {symbolOnePlural} in the line of 6 cells.
balanced-lines.example-incorrect: There are 4 {symbolZeroPlural}, but the row has 6 cells, which means only three {symbolZeroPlural} are allowed.

max-two-consecutive.title: Max Two Consecutive
max-two-consecutive.description-1: No more than two of the same TODO:symbol/number/color can be next to or under each other.
max-two-consecutive.description-2: This means you cannot have three consecutive {symbolOnePlural} or {symbolZeroPlural} in any row or column.
max-two-consecutive.example-correct: Two {symbolOnePlural} in a row, and two {symbolZeroPlural} in a row is allowed.
max-two-consecutive.example-incorrect: Three {symbolOnePlural} in a row is not allowed.

unique-rows-and-columns.title: Unique Rows and Columns
unique-rows-and-columns.description-1: Each row and each column must be unique.
unique-rows-and-columns.description-2: No two rows can be the same, and no two columns can be the same.
unique-rows-and-columns.example-label: This 4x4 puzzle is incorrect, as two rows are the same:

Variations.title: Puzzle Variations
Variations.description: In addition to standard puzzles, there is one puzzle variation available:

Odd.title: Odd-Sized Puzzles
Odd.description-1: In puzzles with an odd number of rows and columns, the rule for balanced lines is slightly altered.
Odd.description-2: In these cases, each line will have one more {symbolOne} than {symbolZero}.
Odd.description-3: This means in a 5x5 grid, each row and column should contain three {symbolOnePlural} and two {symbolZeroPlural}.

overview.page-description: Welcome to Takuzu! This puzzle type, also known as a binary puzzle, is a delightful blend of logic and strategy. Perfect for puzzle enthusiasts and newcomers alike, it offers a unique mental challenge. Our guide is here to help you grasp the basics and discover the fun in every grid. Let's get started!

BasicTechniques.description: Below, we've outlined some fundamental strategies to help you navigate through the puzzles with ease.

pairs-and-sandwiches.title: Identifying Pairs and Sandwiches
pairs-and-sandwiches.description: A direct application of the "max two consecutive" rule is to avoid forming triplets within the puzzle grid.
pairs-and-sandwiches.pairs-description: Whenever you observe two identical {symbolOrColorPlural} next to each other, either horizontally or vertically, this forms a "pair." The cells immediately adjacent to this pair must be filled with the other {symbolOrColor} to prevent creating a sequence of three identical {symbolOrColorPlural} (a triplet).
pairs-and-sandwiches.sandwiches-description: A "sandwich" occurs when an empty cell is flanked by two identical {symbolOrColorPlural}. This setup mandates that the empty cell, effectively the "filling" of the sandwich, be filled with the other {symbolOrColor} to avoid the formation of triplets.

line-completion.title: Completing Rows and Columns
line-completion.description: This technique stems from the "balanced lines" rule, which stipulates that each row and column must contain an equal number of {symbolZeroPlural} and {symbolOnePlural}. As you fill in the puzzle, keep track of the balance within each row and column to guide your placement decisions.
line-completion.tip: A setting is available that adds a horizontal and vertical ruler to the puzzle grid. These rulers display how many of each {symbolOrColor} still need to be placed in that row or column, and highlight whenever a line has none remaining of a single {symbolOrColor}, which means it can be completed with the other {symbolOrColor}.
line-completion.example: This row has 6 cells, which means there are 3 of each {symbolOrColor} required. As you can see in the top row, there are 3 {symbolOnePlural}, which means all other cells should be {symbolZeroPlural}.

unique-lines.title: Unique Rows and Columns
unique-lines.description: This strategy is often not a necessity for solving puzzles, especially at easier difficulties, thanks to the tailored puzzle generation algorithm. Its utility shines on smaller boards or during tougher challenges where other strategies might leave you in a standstill.
unique-lines.when-to-use-text: It's especially helpful in scenarios where a line is almost complete yet cannot be completed using the basic rules of balancing, sandwiches, or pairs. If you're leveraging the rulers setting that indicates the remaining number of each {symbolOrColor} needed in a row or column, pay close attention to lines that require the placement of exactly one {symbolOne} and one {symbolZero}. Compare these scenarios with existing lines to identify the correct placements.
unique-lines.example-label: Consider this 4x4 puzzle. Two rows are already completed, and the first row looks similar to the second row:
unique-lines.example-label-2: It can only be filled in one way to prevent two duplicate rows:

message.notAddedToDbCheats: Puzzle was not saved in your history, because you used cheats.
message.firstTotal: You've solved your first puzzle ever!
message.hardestEver: This was the hardest puzzle you've ever solved, well done!
message.firstOfSizeDifficulty: First time solving a [{dimensions}] puzzle on @:{difficultyKey} difficulty.
message.timeRecordLarge: You were an incredible {improvementPercentage}% faster than your previous best time!
message.timeRecord: You've improved your best time by {differenceSec}s!
message.replayTimeRecord: This is the {numPlaysOrdinal} time you solved this exact puzzle. You were {differenceSec}s faster than your fastest time.
message.almostTimeRecordAbsolute: Ooph, so close to setting a new time record. You were only {differenceSec}s slower then your personal best.
message.almostTimeRecordPercentage: You almost set a new time record! You were only {differencePercentage}% slower.
message.muchBetterThanAverageAbsolute: You solved this puzzle faster than your average by an incredible {differenceSec}s!
message.muchBetterThanAveragePercentage: That was much faster than average! You were {improvementPercentage}% faster.
message.betterThanAverage: You were {differenceSec}s faster than your previous average.
message.worstEver: This was your toughest challenge yet, setting a new personal record for the longest time taken.
message.nearlyWorstEver: Almost your slowest solve, but you still managed to beat your personal worst time!
message.replayPlaysTotal: This is the {numPlaysOrdinal} time you've solved this exact same puzzle, with your best time being {bestPreviousTimeMinSec}.
message.playsTotal: You've solved a total of {totalSolved} puzzles now.
message.playsConfigTotal: You've solved a total of {count} puzzles with {dimensions} dimensions at @:{difficultyKey} difficulty.
message.playsConfigToday: You've played {count} puzzles with {dimensions} dimensions today at @:{difficultyKey} difficulty.
